# 4.2 Bodyweight Training: Using Your Body to Get Stronger!

## Learning Objectives

By the end of this session, you'll be able to:
- Explain why bodyweight exercises are a good way to get stronger
- Show how to do at least 3 different bodyweight exercises correctly
- Create a short workout using your favorite bodyweight exercises

Your body is actually a brilliant piece of exercise equipment! Instead of using weights or machines, bodyweight training uses the weight of your own body to make your muscles work. When you do a push-up, you're lifting part of your body weight with your arms. When you do a squat, you're using your leg muscles to lower and lift your body.

The best part? You don't need any special kit, and you can do these exercises almost anywhere! Whether you're at home watching telly, in your bedroom before bed, or in a small space in your home, you can squeeze in a quick workout to make your muscles stronger.

## Awesome Bodyweight Exercises You Can Try

### For Your Arms
- **Wall Push-ups**: Stand facing a wall with your hands on the wall at shoulder height. Bend your elbows to bring your chest toward the wall, then push back. It's a gentler version of a regular push-up—perfect for beginners!
- **Chair Dips**: Sit on the edge of a sturdy chair. Place your hands on the edge of the seat next to your hips. Slide your bottom off the chair and lower yourself by bending your elbows. Push back up to the starting position.

### For Your Shoulders
- **Arm Circles**: Stand with your arms out to the sides like aeroplane wings. Make small circles with your arms, first forward for 15-20 circles, then backward for 15-20 circles. Feel the burn!
- **Shoulder Taps**: Get into a push-up position (you can do this on your knees if it's too hard). Keeping your body still, lift one hand and tap the opposite shoulder, then switch sides. Try to complete 5-10 taps on each side at your own pace.

### For Your Chest
- **Push-ups**: Start in a plank position with hands under shoulders. Lower your chest toward the floor by bending your elbows, then push back up.
- **Too hard? Try knee push-ups**: Same as above, but with your knees on the floor for less resistance.

### For Your Back
- **Superman**: Lie on your stomach with arms stretched out in front of you. Lift your arms, chest, and legs off the floor and hold for 2-3 seconds. Just like the superhero flying!
- **Backward Snow Angels**: Lie on your stomach with arms by your sides. Lift your chest slightly and move your arms like you're making a snow angel. Complete as many as feels comfortable for you.

### For Your Core (Abs and Lower Back)
- **Plank**: Hold a push-up position (on hands or forearms) with your body in a straight line from head to heels. Start by holding for 10 seconds and gradually increase your time as you get stronger.
- **Curl-ups**: Lie on your back with knees bent and feet flat. Place your hands on your thighs. Curl up until your hands reach your knees, then lower back down.
- **Bird-dog**: Start on your hands and knees. Reach your right arm forward while extending your left leg backward. Hold for 2 seconds, return to start, then switch sides.

### For Your Legs
- **Squats**: Stand with feet shoulder-width apart. Bend your knees and push your hips back like you're sitting in an invisible chair. Stand back up and repeat.
- **Lunges**: Take a big step forward with one foot and lower your body until both knees are bent at 90-degree angles. Push back up and repeat with the other leg.
- **Calf Raises**: Stand with feet hip-width apart. Rise up onto your toes as high as you can, then lower back down.

## Doing It Right (and Making It Work for You)
When doing these exercises, remember:
- Keep your back straight during planks and push-ups (no sagging or arching!)
- Don't let your knees go past your toes during squats and lunges
- Move slowly and with control—no bouncing or jerking!

If an exercise is too hard:
- Do fewer repetitions (reps means how many times you do an exercise)
- Take breaks when you need them
- Try the easier versions (like knee push-ups instead of regular push-ups)

If an exercise is too easy:
- Do more repetitions
- Hold positions longer
- Try the harder versions (like regular push-ups instead of wall push-ups)

## Fun Ways to Practise
Try these fun activities to practise your new bodyweight exercises:

1. **Personal Exercise Calendar**: Create a calendar marking which exercises you'll do each day. Check them off as you complete them to track your progress!

2. **Exercise Cards**: Write different exercises on index cards or pieces of paper. Shuffle them and draw one card at a time to determine which exercise to do and how many times.

3. **Personal Fitness Challenge**: Set personal goals like holding a plank for 5 seconds longer each day or adding one more squat to your routine each time.

4. **Create Your Own Routine**: Design a 5-minute workout using your favourite exercises from this lesson. Practice it daily and see how you improve!

## Over to You
Take a moment to think about these questions:
- Which exercises did you find easiest? Which were most challenging?
- How did your body feel during and after the exercises?
- Where might you fit these exercises into your daily routine?
- Could you create a quick 3-minute workout using your three favourite exercises?

After trying the exercises, write down your thoughts in a notebook or on your device. This will help you track your progress and identify which exercises you enjoy most.

## Wrapping Up
Bodyweight exercises are a brilliant way to build strength and flexibility without needing any special equipment. By practising these exercises regularly, you'll notice improvements in your strength, endurance, and how your body feels overall. Remember, everyone starts somewhere—it's okay if you can only do a few repetitions at first. Keep at it, and you'll get stronger every day!

Next time you're watching telly or have a few minutes to spare, try doing some squats, push-ups, or planks. Your muscles will thank you!

3. Formulaic transition phrases
4. Artificial enthusiasm markers
5. Repetitive explanation patterns

   - Maintain ALL original section headings exactly as written
   - Preserve all educational substance and learning objectives

2. PATTERN ELIMINATION (IMPORTANT):
   - Replace predictable metaphors and comparison frameworks

   - Convert formulaic transitions to natural connections

2. Focus exclusively on language patterns and voice authenticity

# 4.2 Bodyweight Training: Using Your Body to Get Stronger!

## Learning Objectives

By the end of this session, you'll be able to:
- Explain why bodyweight exercises are a good way to get stronger
- Show how to do at least 3 different bodyweight exercises correctly
- Create a short workout using your favorite bodyweight exercises

Your body works as natural exercise equipment! Bodyweight training relies on your own weight to challenge your muscles. During push-ups, your arms lift a portion of your body weight. When performing squats, your leg muscles control lowering and raising your body.

The real advantage? These exercises require no equipment and fit almost anywhere in your day. You can do them while watching television, before bedtime, or in any small space at home to strengthen your muscles.

## Awesome Bodyweight Exercises You Can Try

### For Your Arms
- **Wall Push-ups**: Face a wall with hands at shoulder height. Bend your elbows to bring your chest toward the wall, then push back. This works well for beginners before moving to standard push-ups.
- **Chair Dips**: Sit on a sturdy chair's edge. Place hands beside your hips on the seat edge. Slide forward off the chair and lower yourself by bending elbows. Push up to return to start position.

### For Your Shoulders
- **Arm Circles**: Stand with arms extended sideways. Make small circles forward 15-20 times, then backward 15-20 times. Your shoulders will definitely feel this!
- **Shoulder Taps**: Begin in push-up position (knees down if needed). Keep your body steady while lifting one hand to tap the opposite shoulder, then switch. Complete 5-10 taps per side at your own speed.

### For Your Chest
- **Push-ups**: Start in plank position, hands under shoulders. Lower your chest toward the floor by bending elbows, then push back up.
- **Too hard? Try knee push-ups**: Keep the same form but with knees on the floor to reduce the weight you're lifting.

### For Your Back
- **Superman**: Lie facedown with arms extended forward. Lift your arms, chest, and legs off the floor and hold 2-3 seconds.
- **Backward Snow Angels**: Lie on your stomach, arms at your sides. Lift your chest slightly and move arms in a snow angel pattern. Do as many as comfortable.

### For Your Core (Abs and Lower Back)
- **Plank**: Hold push-up position (on hands or forearms) with your body forming a straight line. Start with 10 seconds and increase time as you build strength.
- **Curl-ups**: Lie on your back, knees bent, feet flat. Place hands on thighs and curl up until hands reach knees, then lower back down.
- **Bird-dog**: Begin on hands and knees. Extend right arm forward while stretching left leg backward. Hold 2 seconds, return to start, switch sides.

### For Your Legs
- **Squats**: Stand with feet shoulder-width apart. Bend knees and push hips back as if sitting down. Stand back up and repeat.
- **Lunges**: Step forward with one foot and lower until both knees form 90-degree angles. Push back up and repeat with the other leg.
- **Calf Raises**: Stand with feet hip-width apart. Rise onto your toes as high as possible, then lower back down.

## Doing It Right (and Making It Work for You)
When doing these exercises, remember:
- Maintain a straight back during planks and push-ups without sagging or arching
- Keep your knees behind your toes during squats and lunges
- Move with control—avoid bouncing or jerking movements

If an exercise feels too challenging:
- Reduce the number of repetitions
- Rest when needed
- Use modified versions (knee push-ups instead of standard ones)

If an exercise seems too simple:
- Increase repetitions
- Extend how long you hold positions
- Progress to more difficult versions (standard push-ups instead of wall push-ups)

## Fun Ways to Practise
Try these activities to build your bodyweight exercise habit:

1. **Personal Exercise Calendar**: Mark which exercises you'll do each day on a calendar. Check them off to see your progress!

2. **Exercise Cards**: Write exercises on paper slips. Shuffle and draw to decide which movement to perform and how many times.

3. **Personal Fitness Challenge**: Set goals like extending plank time by 5 seconds daily or adding one squat to each workout.

4. **Create Your Own Routine**: Design a 5-minute workout with exercises you enjoy from this lesson. Practice daily to track improvement!

## Over to You
Consider these questions:
- Which exercises felt easiest? Which challenged you most?
- What sensations did you notice during and after exercising?
- When could you include these exercises in your daily schedule?
- Could you build a quick 3-minute workout using your three favorite exercises?

Record your thoughts in a notebook or on your device after trying these exercises. This helps track your progress and identify which movements you prefer.

## Wrapping Up
Bodyweight exercises offer an effective way to build strength and flexibility without special equipment. Regular practice leads to improvements in strength, endurance, and overall physical well-being. Everyone starts somewhere—it's perfectly fine if you can only complete a few repetitions initially. Consistent effort brings daily strength gains!

Next time you watch television or have a spare moment, try a few squats, push-ups, or planks. Your muscles will benefit from the work!
